Panel B of Figure 8 relates the SFRatio to the standard normal distribution. Note that
the SFR is the number of standard deviations below the mean. Thus, the portfolio with
the larger SFR has the lower probability of returns below the threshold return, which
is a return of 0% in our example. Using a z-table for negative values, we can find the
probabilities in the left-hand tails as indicated. These probabilities (25% for Portfolio A
and 20% for Portfolio B) are also the shortfall risk for a target return of 0%, that is, the
probability of negative returns. Portfolio B has the higher SFR which means it has the
lower probability of negative returns.
